title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
On-Farm Research Success

Ask the Right Question (refer to Mark’s session this AM)
Ask what data will be collected
Consider paddock history and variation
Pick the right trial design (refer to Point 3 above & previous session)

Include a control treatment for a baseline!

Replicate and randomise (refer to previous session)
Collect the data
Share the raw data with AAGI

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Ensuring You Have Quality Data

Ensure the trial design is valid and fit for purpose.
Ensure the trial design is recorded correctly.
Identify and control sources of noise.
Implement protocols to avoid mistakes in running the trial and recording of observations.
Always provide the raw data to the biometrician.
Record ancillary details.

Check Your Data

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Best Practices to Follow



All columns supplied with the trial design should be retained
Every plot needs a unique identifier (e.g., plot number)
Avoid copy-paste (easy to introduce errors)
Ensure embedded equations reference the correct columns

Or better yet, don’t do calculations in the spreadsheet at all






Source: Dr Karyn Reeves, SAGI-West

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
section: Basic Rules for Data in Spreadsheets
text:
Basic Rules for Data in Spreadsheets

Be Consistent

Use the same layout if you have multiple files
Use the same variable names (also if you have multiple files)
Only use one variable name, e.g., S10 is different than S 10




 From Broman and Woo (2018)

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Choose Good Names for Things



Good Name
Good Alternative
Avoid




max_temp_C
MaxTemp
Maximum Temp (˚C)


precipitation_mm
precip
precmm


mean_year_growth
MeanYearGrowth
Mean growth/year


yield_kg_ha
yield
yield kg/ha


observation_o1
first_observation
1st Obs.





The good names include the measured variable and the units. The alternatives are less descriptive but are clear and do not have spaces in them. The avoid have spaces and upper and lower case or are ambiguous.


 After Broman and Woo (2018)

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Write Dates as YYYY-MM-DD (ISO 8601)

A spreadsheet with inconsistent date formats. This spreadsheet does not adhere to recommendations for consistency of date format. From Broman and Woo (2018). Also see https://xkcd.com/1179.

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
No Empty Cells

Examples of spreadsheets that violate the no empty cells recommendation. (a) A spreadsheet where only the first of several repeated values was included. (b) A spreadsheet with a complicated layout and some implicit column headers, from Broman and Woo (2018).

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
section: Put Just One Thing in a Cell
text:
Put Just One Thing in a Cell

e.g., Don’t use rep-plot for a header and use 1-1, 1-2…2-1, in the column, etc.
Do use rep and plot as headers and have the values in separated columns

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Make It a Rectangle

Examples of spreadsheets with nonrectangular layouts. These layouts are likely to cause problems in analysis, from Broman and Woo (2018).Example A, what not to do.

Keep your data tidy and in a rectangle so that it’s easy to analyse when you send it to AAGI. These examples have many empty cells in-between values. Computers don’t like these sorts of holes in the data (and thus neither do the biometricians using the computers).

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Make It a Rectangle

A spreadsheet with two header rows. It is better to have a single header row, from Broman and Woo (2018).Example B, what not to do.

This is a common example of having two header rows. Following is an example of how to integrate this header row into a column for a nice rectangular data set.

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Make It a Rectangle

An example spreadsheet of the previous example’s data in a rectangular layout, from Broman and Woo (2018).Yes, do this!

We can see here that we’ve incorporated the week heading into a column, yes, it’s repeated but that’s what the computer will look for when the analysis is run and will not affect anything. In fact, it’s preferred!

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Create a Data Dictionary

An example data dictionary, from Broman and Woo (2018).
My suggestion is that this goes in the trial protocol that is provided to AAGI with the data.

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
section: Do Not Use Colour as Data
text:
Do Not Use Colour as Data

Highlighting in spreadsheets.(a) A potential outlier indicated by highlighting the cell.(b) The preferred method for indicating outliers, via an additional column, from Broman and Woo (2018).

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
section: Save Data in Plain Text Files (e.g., CSV)
text:
Save Data in Plain Text Files (e.g., CSV)

(a) An example spreadsheet. (b) The same data as a plain text file in CSV format, from Broman and Woo (2018).

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Lastly

No calculations in the raw data file
Make backups
Use data validation to avoid errors



Avoid calculations in the raw data that you send to AAGI. Just provide the raw data, AAGI will perform the calcuations to create mean values and other summaries as necessary. Performing calculations in the spreadsheet can lead to errors and obscure the raw data if it’s not provided to AAGI pre-calculated.
Make backups!
Excel can validate your data. I won’t go into it here, but it has the capabilities to enforce cell types to help you ensure that you don’t put a date in a yield column that should be a number not a date, or a weed name (text) in a weed count column (numeric).


 From Broman and Woo (2018)

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
Exercise




 Exercise (20 min)


Working with your partner on the experiment you designed this morning.

Create a trial protocol that details the:

Treatments and
Data to be collected.

Draw or list the spreadsheet headings for the data you will be collecting to send to AAGI.

Describe the date format you will use,
Describe what you will use to describe missing data and
Describe what descriptions need to be included in the data dictionary/protocol for AAGI to refer to.

title: GGA training session 3 – Trial Protocols and Best Data Practices
text:
References









Broman, Karl W., and Kara H. Woo. 2018. “Data Organization in Spreadsheets.” The American Statistician 72 (1): 2–10. https://doi.org/10.1080/00031305.2017.1375989.
